Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: Children are about to finish school, and the parent should pick them up
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Story: I glanced at the clock, feeling the familiar tug in my chest. It was almost three, and my children would be waiting at the school gate, scanning the crowd for my face. I promised them I’d be there—just like every Friday. But today, the church had called an urgent meeting, right before the evening service. As a committed member, I was expected to help set up and lead the opening prayer. Pastor had reminded us last Sunday how important it was to show up, to be present for the community, especially now when so many depended on us. I could hear my daughter’s voice in my mind, “You’ll be there, right, Mom?” and at the same time, I pictured the disappointed looks from my church family if I didn’t show. My heart pounded as I stood in the hallway, keys in hand, torn between the school and the church, between my children’s trust and my faith community’s expectations. I closed my eyes, wishing I could be in two places at once, feeling the weight of both promises pressing down on me.
